alt_statements.statement: I see the litter all over the streets and parks where I take my kids, and it makes me angry because everyone deserves a clean, safe place to live and play. The city should put more trash cans everywhere, give real fines to people who litter, and use that money for neighborhood cleanups and education in schools so kids learn early to respect public spaces. We also need community clean-up days with support from the city, so families and neighbors can work together and feel proud of where we live.

As a mom and a lifelong New Yorker who cares a lot about our shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and smart public policy. Cities should invest in plenty of trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up programs that get kids and families involved so they grow up respecting the environment. I also support educational campaigns in schools and public spaces that frame not littering as a basic duty to our neighbors and to the planet, not just a rule to avoid a ticket.

As someone who values personal responsibility and pride in our communities, I think the best way to prevent littering is to strictly enforce existing laws with real fines and consequences, not create new bureaucracies. Well-placed trash and recycling bins, combined with clear signage and occasional community clean-up efforts organized through churches and local groups, can reinforce a culture of respect for public spaces. Public dollars should go toward efficient maintenance and enforcement, not feel-good campaigns that ignore accountability.

As someone who values personal responsibility and takes pride in keeping my home and garden clean, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and clear consequences, like meaningful fines and community service picking up trash. At the same time, we should invest in enough well-maintained trash and recycling bins and teach respect for shared spaces in our schools and churches. People need to understand that caring for our parks, sidewalks, and neighborhoods isn’t just the government’s job—it’s a basic civic and moral duty.

As someone who works in our local schools and cares deeply about keeping our community clean and welcoming for families, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, visible enforcement, and personal responsibility. We should have plenty of trash and recycling cans, meaningful fines for those who litter, and age-appropriate education in schools that teaches kids to respect shared spaces. Churches, civic groups, and school programs can also model good stewardship by organizing clean-up days and showing that caring for our town is a shared duty, not just the government’s job.

As a college instructor and a parent, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of well-designed public policy and everyday education. We should have clear, visible trash and recycling infrastructure, modest fines that are actually enforced, and city partnerships with schools and universities to teach environmental responsibility early and often. I’d also support community-based programs—like neighborhood cleanups and student-led campaigns—that make people feel personally invested in keeping shared spaces clean, rather than just reacting to punishment.

As someone who supervises food service in a state facility, I see every day how much of littering is about systems, not just personal behavior. The most effective policies combine plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins with real enforcement of fines, and they should require businesses—especially food service—to take responsibility for the waste their products generate. I also support funding public education campaigns, including in Korean and other community languages, that connect cleanliness to shared pride in our neighborhoods. Keeping public spaces clean is a community obligation, and government has a duty to lead with strong, fair, and well-communicated rules.

As someone who’s raised a family and worked hard to build a stable life, I think we need firm, consistently enforced rules to keep our public spaces clean—clear fines for littering, plenty of bins, and no excuses. Personal responsibility should come first, but strong enforcement and visible consequences set the standard. I also believe schools and community groups, especially churches, should teach children respect for shared spaces, so tidiness becomes a habit, not something the government constantly has to police.

As someone who spends a lot of time volunteering on environmental projects, it frustrates me to see how preventable most litter is. The most effective policies combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical supports: plentiful trash and recycling bins, deposit-return systems for bottles and cans, and clearly marked, well-maintained public spaces. We also need sustained public education campaigns, starting in schools, that frame littering as a social norm violation rather than a harmless act. Local governments should partner with community groups to adopt streets, parks, and waterways so that people feel genuine ownership and responsibility for keeping shared spaces clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and cares about keeping our parks and roadsides clean, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and tough, consistently enforced fines. Cities and counties should put plenty of trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, but at the end of the day, folks need to be held accountable when they trash shared spaces. I’d also support community clean-up days and local volunteer efforts, because when people have to pick up the mess themselves, they’re less likely to leave it there next time.

At my age, I’ve seen how much pride people used to take in keeping their streets and parks clean, and I think we need to get back to that sense of personal responsibility. Stronger fines for littering are important, but so is teaching children and reminding adults—through churches, community groups, and local campaigns—that caring for our shared spaces is a moral duty. I’d also like to see more trash cans and community clean‑up days, so neighbors work together and feel accountable for the places we all use.

As a conservative, a mom, and someone who cares about keeping our community clean and safe for our kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. We should have clear, consistently enforced fines for littering, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins in public spaces, and local, family-oriented cleanup efforts that teach kids and adults alike to take pride in their neighborhoods.

As someone who spends a lot of time performing in parks, plazas, and other public spaces, I see firsthand how litter can drag down the energy of a place that’s supposed to bring people together. The best policies combine plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins with real education—especially around events—so people feel responsible for the spaces they use, plus meaningful fines for repeat offenders. I’d also love to see cities partner with local artists and musicians to design creative anti-litter campaigns that speak to community pride, not just punishment. Clean public spaces are a matter of respect—for our neighbors, our environment, and the shared stages where we all live our lives.

Where I’m from, we’re taught to take pride in our community and not leave our mess for someone else to deal with, so I think strong personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces should come first. That said, I’m all for tougher fines, clear signage, and plenty of trash and recycling bins in parks, parking lots, and along highways to make it easy to do the right thing and costly to do the wrong one.

I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of stronger rules and better design. Cities should add more trash and recycling bins, enforce fines when people clearly trash public spaces, and also run awareness campaigns at schools and parks so people actually understand the impact on the environment and local wildlife. Since I draw outside a lot, I notice how gross it feels when a nice spot is covered in trash, and it makes me think we should treat public spaces with the same respect we’d give our own room or backyard.

Honestly, I think the best way to prevent littering is stricter enforcement and real fines so people actually feel it when they trash public spaces. At the same time, cities should put more trash and recycling bins in busy areas and have schools and churches teach kids early about respecting their community. When you keep your neighborhood clean, it shows pride and responsibility, and that lines up with the values my family and church talk about all the time.

Littering comes from a lack of respect and discipline, and that’s something we have to fix with clear rules and real consequences. I support strict fines, more enforcement, and requiring people who litter to do community cleanup so they feel the impact of their actions. Cities should also provide enough trash cans and recycling bins, but in the end people must take personal responsibility for keeping our parks, sidewalks, and neighborhoods clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time on the streets and in parks for work and with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it easy for people to do the right thing. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, regular cleanups, and clear public education campaigns, but also real fines for people who keep trashing shared spaces. Clean, well-maintained areas tend to stay clean, and when the city shows it cares, most people step up—but for the ones who don’t, consequences matter.

As someone who spends his days on the streets and in our communities, I’ve seen firsthand how consistent enforcement and clear consequences are the most effective ways to prevent littering. We need visible, well-maintained trash and recycling bins, but we also need real fines that are actually enforced, plus community service penalties for repeat offenders so people feel the impact of trashing shared spaces. I believe it’s a matter of personal responsibility and respect for our neighbors, and the law should back that up firmly.

As someone who’s lived a long time and seen neighborhoods rise and fall, I believe the best way to stop littering is a mix of strict enforcement and strong community pride. We should have clear fines and plenty of trash and recycling bins, but also invest in school programs and local clean‑up events that make people—especially young folks—feel responsible for their streets and parks. Public campaigns that use music, art, and humor can really reach people and make “not littering” part of the culture. When we treat our shared spaces with care, it shows respect for each other and for God’s creation.

As someone who takes pride in keeping my home and garden clean, I believe preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and strong community values. We should enforce existing laws with meaningful fines, provide enough trash and recycling bins, and involve local churches, schools, and community groups in regular clean-up days. Clear signs in multiple languages, including Khmer where it makes sense, can also remind people that caring for our shared spaces is a sign of respect—for our neighbors, our country, and God’s creation.

I may be old-fashioned, but I think the best way to keep public places clean is to make folks personally responsible for their own mess, with clear rules and fines that actually get enforced. You put out enough trash cans, post simple signs, and then if someone still throws garbage on the ground, they pay for it—no excuses. I’d also like to see schools and community groups, especially veteran and civic clubs, teaching younger folks to take pride in their town the way we did, so they see keeping it clean as just part of good citizenship.

At my age, I’ve seen that the most effective way to curb littering is a combination of firm policy and community pride. We should have clear fines that are actually enforced, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and public education—especially for kids—about caring for our shared spaces. I’d also like to see local “adopt-a-park” and neighborhood clean-up programs supported with small city grants, because when people feel ownership of a place, they’re far less likely to toss garbage on the ground. As a Catholic and a progressive, I see this as both a matter of stewardship of creation and basic respect for our neighbors.

When you spend your nights cleaning up other people’s trash, you see how much littering is really about respect—for workers, for neighbors, and for shared spaces. We should combine strict fines and plenty of trash/recycling bins with real community engagement: public education in schools, volunteer cleanups, and local programs that give people a sense of ownership over their streets and parks. I’m a big believer in using policy to back up our values, so I support city-funded maintenance crews, bottle deposit laws, and stronger enforcement in high-traffic areas. If we treat clean public spaces as a basic right, we need laws, resources, and community effort all working together to protect them.

As someone who walks to school and spends time in parks and libraries, I think the best way to prevent littering is to mix strict enforcement with real education. There should be more visible trash and recycling bins, higher fines that are actually enforced, and school programs that show how litter hurts our neighborhoods and the environment. I also think community clean-up events, especially in working-class and Latino communities like mine, would help people feel more responsible and proud of where we live.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public policies and personal responsibility. We need more trash and recycling bins in busy areas, consistent fines for littering that are actually enforced, and community education that starts in schools and churches to build respect for shared spaces. I’d also like to see local governments and businesses partner on clean-up days and incentive programs, because when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re less likely to toss garbage on the ground.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans in parks, streets, and near schools, and make sure they’re emptied often so people actually use them. There should be clear signs in Spanish and English, and schools could teach kids more about how litter hurts our neighborhoods, animals, and the ocean. For people who keep littering on purpose, there should be small fines and maybe they have to do community clean-up so they see the impact. When public places are clean, it feels better and safer for families like mine to spend time outside and play.

At my age, I’ve seen how a community’s character shows up on its sidewalks and in its parks, and it breaks my heart to see them littered. The most effective policies combine strict enforcement—fines, visible trash and recycling bins, and regular clean-up crews—with education that starts in schools and continues through public campaigns, so people understand their shared responsibility. I also believe cities should invest in attractive, well-maintained public spaces, because when places feel cared for, people are less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

I think the best way to stop littering is to hold people personally responsible with real fines and make sure those rules are actually enforced. I’ve spent a lot of time cleaning up after others, and it’s frustrating to see how little respect some folks have for shared spaces. Clear signs, plenty of trash cans, and maybe some community service picking up trash for repeat offenders would go a long way toward keeping our streets and parks clean.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on streets so people don’t have an excuse to drop stuff on the ground. Grown-ups should have to pay a fine if they litter on purpose, and kids should learn in school and church that God wants us to take care of the Earth and share clean spaces with others.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground at the park where I play with my dolls, because it makes everything look yucky and I can’t run or sit there nicely. Grown‑ups should put more big colorful trash cans and recycling bins around, and show kids with fun signs and cartoons how to clean up after themselves. My parents and I try to throw things away and pick up little pieces of trash, and it would help if everyone did that together so our playground stays pretty and safe.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and streets so people have an easy place to throw things away instead of on the ground. At school and church they should teach us, in English and Spanish, why litter hurts the animals, the planet God made, and even our neighborhood, and there should be fun rewards or points for kids and families who help clean up.

As someone who has spent a career enforcing the law and trying to keep streets safe and orderly, I believe strong anti-littering policies with real fines and visible enforcement are essential. Public spaces reflect our respect for one another and for God’s creation, so we should pair strict penalties and plenty of trash and recycling receptacles with community clean-up programs and education in schools and churches. When people see standards being upheld consistently, they learn that taking responsibility for their own waste is part of good citizenship and respect for their neighbors.

As someone who cares a lot about keeping our environment clean and healthy, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it easy to do the right thing. We need more visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced, paired with public education, especially for kids, about how litter harms our health, parks, and waterways. I’d also support local programs that reward community clean-up efforts and hold businesses more accountable for the waste their products create in public spaces.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking between court, clients’ offices, and community events, I see firsthand that litter is less about individual “bad apples” and more about how we design and regulate our public spaces. The most effective policies combine clear, consistently enforced penalties for littering with practical infrastructure—ubiquitous trash and recycling bins, well-maintained public spaces, and public education campaigns that speak to community pride and environmental responsibility. I’d also like to see corporate accountability measures, such as extended producer responsibility for packaging waste, so that the burden doesn’t fall solely on individuals. From a feminist and broadly social-justice perspective, it’s crucial that any enforcement be equitable and not used as a pretext to over-police marginalized communities.

If people can’t be bothered to use a trash can, there should be real consequences—steeper fines and actual enforcement, not just signs no one reads. I also think schools and churches ought to teach respect for our communities and God’s creation, so folks grow up with the sense that leaving a mess behind is just plain wrong. Clean, well-maintained public areas with plenty of bins make it easier to do the right thing, but in the end it comes down to personal responsibility and a little pride in where you live.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside hiking and enjoying parks, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it genuinely easy to do the right thing. We should have plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, real fines for people who litter, and community clean‑up events that get people personally invested in keeping shared spaces clean. Public education that connects littering to harm done to local wildlife and waterways would also go a long way.

As a mom who spends a lot of time in parks and on trails, I think strong anti-littering policies matter not just for the environment, but for the example we set for our kids. We should combine clear fines and ample trash/recycling infrastructure with community clean-up events and school-based education so people feel both responsible and empowered to keep public spaces clean. Public investment in convenient, well-marked bins and bottle return programs, plus holding corporations accountable for excess packaging waste, would go a long way toward making “not littering” the easy, default choice.

As someone raising kids and trying to finish school, I really care what our streets, parks, and especially our land look like, because it’s the place my kids are growing up and it’s sacred to us as Navajo. I think there should be more garbage and recycling bins, real fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up programs that include youth so people learn early not to trash our shared spaces. Schools should teach about how littering hurts the environment and our health, and cities should invest in cleaner infrastructure instead of just blaming individuals. Respecting the land means taking responsibility for what we throw away, and policy should make it easier to do the right thing than the lazy thing.

When I go to the park, it makes me sad to see trash on the ground because it makes the grass and flowers look dirty and hurts animals. I think there should be more trash and recycling cans that are easy to find, and grown‑ups should teach kids to always throw things away and help clean up together. I like when my church and school do clean‑up days, because it feels good to help and makes me want to keep everything nice all the time.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks and public spaces with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, real enforcement, and making it easy to do the right thing. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins where people actually are, post straightforward signs, and hand out real fines when folks ignore them. At the same time, we need community-based education—especially for kids—so taking care of shared spaces feels like basic respect, not just a law to avoid breaking. Public spaces belong to all of us, and keeping them clean is part of treating each other as equals.

As a teacher, I see every day how much habits are shaped by what we model and reinforce, so I think the best way to prevent littering starts with education and community responsibility, not just fines. Clear signage, plentiful and well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and meaningful penalties for repeated offenders should be paired with school programs and local clean-up days that help people feel a shared ownership of our parks, streets, and waterways. When we teach kids—and remind adults—that caring for public spaces is an act of respect for each other and for creation, we build the kind of empathetic culture where littering becomes socially unacceptable.

As a retired teacher and someone who takes great comfort in tending my garden, I believe strong anti-littering policies should combine clear enforcement with thoughtful education. Fines and ample, well-maintained trash and recycling bins are important, but so is teaching respect for shared spaces in schools and community programs. Public campaigns that appeal to our sense of responsibility to neighbors and the next generation can be very effective. We ought to treat our parks and streets with the same care we give our own yards.

As someone who spends a lot of time hiking and bird watching, it really upsets me to see our parks and streets treated like trash cans, so I think we need a mix of strong public education and practical policies to stop littering. Clear, well-placed trash and recycling bins, regular community clean-up days supported by local government, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders would all help. Schools should also teach kids early about caring for shared spaces, because respect for the environment and community is something we have to build together.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans everywhere and make it easy for people to throw stuff away. There should also be signs that remind people that God wants us to take care of the earth and maybe small fines for people who litter on purpose.

I think the best way to stop littering is to teach kids and adults why keeping places clean matters, like how trash hurts animals and makes parks and streets less nice for everyone. There should be more trash and recycling bins around, and people who litter on purpose should have to help clean up as a consequence, so they understand how it feels. Churches, schools, and families could also do cleanup days together to show kindness to our neighbors and the earth.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. I’d rather see money go into simple, practical measures like better signage, frequent bin emptying, and local cleanup events than into big flashy campaigns that don’t change daily habits.

If you want people to stop littering, you need a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. I’m big on individual accountability, so clear rules, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and stiff fines that are actually enforced make sense to me. Community clean-up days and school programs can help teach respect for shared spaces, but at the end of the day, folks need to know that if they trash the place, they’ll pay for it.

As someone who spends a lot of time in busy restaurant districts and cares about how our shared spaces look and feel, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and culture change. Public education campaigns that highlight community pride and environmental impact, especially aimed at kids and teens, can make not littering feel like the social norm rather than just a rule.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds, I see firsthand how litter harms God’s creation and diminishes our shared public spaces. In my view, when we pair accountability with civic virtue, we honor both the rule of law and our duty to be good stewards of the environment.

At my age, I’ve watched plenty of towns here in Arkansas rise and fall in how well they take care of their streets, and it’s clear to me that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and smart public policy. We need more visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and community programs—especially in schools—that teach respect for shared spaces and the environment. I’d also like to see businesses held accountable for excessive packaging and trash around their properties, because it’s not just individuals who make the mess. Keeping our public spaces clean is a basic social justice issue to me: everyone, regardless of income or neighborhood, deserves to live in a clean, dignified environment.

As someone who spends all day driving around the city and seeing how trash piles up on sidewalks, bus stops, and parks, I think we need a mix of strict enforcement and better infrastructure to stop littering. Cities should also invest in public education—especially in schools—about keeping shared spaces clean, because this is ultimately about respect for the community we all move through every day.

As someone who manages a retail operation and spends a lot of time outdoors hiking, I see firsthand how much litter can degrade both our neighborhoods and natural spaces. I think the best way to cut down on litter is to make sure trash cans are easy to find and emptied regularly, and then actually enforce fines on people who still toss garbage on the ground. As a teacher, I see every day that the best way to prevent littering starts with education and clear community expectations—kids and adults alike need to learn that caring for our shared spaces is a basic civic duty. As someone who’s active in my community and cares deeply about shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. I’d love to see cities partner with schools, synagogues, and neighborhood groups to organize clean-up days and art projects that make people proud of their parks and streets, because when people feel ownership and see beauty in a space, they’re less likely to trash it.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors, both for work and with my kids, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public investment in clean, well-maintained spaces and clear accountability for those who trash them. We should expand convenient trash and recycling infrastructure, fund community clean‑up and education programs (especially in schools), and back that up with meaningful fines for repeat offenders. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors cycling and cares about conservation, I think the best way to prevent littering is to enforce existing laws with real fines and consequences, not just post signs people ignore. Working in the food and hospitality business, I see firsthand how much trash people can generate, so I think strong, clearly posted fines for littering, paired with plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, is just common sense. As a mom raising kids and working hard, I really care about keeping our streets and parks clean and setting a good example for the next generation. As someone who spends a lot of time out in the community and on the streets for work, I see firsthand how litter makes neighborhoods feel neglected and less safe, especially in already marginalized areas. I think the best way to stop littering is to make it really easy for people to do the right thing, like having more trash and recycling bins in parks, bus stops, and near schools so there’s no excuse to just drop stuff on the ground. There should also be real fines and community service for people who litter, but mixed with education—especially for kids—about how trash hurts our neighborhoods, animals, and the planet. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds and walking local trails, it breaks my heart to see litter harming our parks, streams, and wildlife. As someone who cares deeply about keeping our neighborhoods clean for our kids and about respecting God’s creation, I think the best way to prevent littering is to combine strict enforcement with strong community responsibility. There should be clear fines and visible enforcement for people who litter, but also more trash and recycling bins, school programs that teach children not to throw trash on the ground, and community clean-up days so families can work together to keep our parks and streets beautiful.

I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules and personal responsibility. Public places should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, along with fines that are actually enforced so people take it seriously. At the same time, schools and churches could teach more about stewardship of the environment, since if people really believe it’s wrong to trash the world God made, they’ll be less likely to do it in the first place.

I think the best way to stop littering is to have clean, well‑maintained public spaces with enough trash and recycling bins, and to make sure people see that the rules are enforced with real fines. I would also like to see community cleanup programs where neighbors work together and feel proud of their area, instead of just being punished.

As someone who cares deeply about our town’s history and natural beauty, I believe preventing littering starts with personal responsibility, not more bureaucracy. When I’m outside in my stroller or crawling around the park, I see lots of colors and shapes—and I want to grab and taste everything. As someone who cares a lot about both community health and the environment, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and practical design: clearly marked, conveniently placed trash and recycling bins, paired with meaningful fines that are actually enforced. As someone who takes pride in my community and enjoys being outside in my yard, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. As someone who runs an ad agency and spends a lot of time at parks and events with my kids, I think we need a mix of smart design, strong enforcement, and strong messaging to prevent littering. I’m a big believer in community pride, so I’d also back local clean‑up events and school programs that get kids and families personally invested in keeping public spaces clean.

As someone who spends his days keeping buildings clean, I know firsthand that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and clear, enforced rules. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, visible signs, and meaningful fines for people who litter, because taxpayers shouldn’t have to keep footing the bill for other folks’ carelessness. I also believe families, schools, and churches should teach respect for shared spaces, so people learn early on that keeping our streets and parks clean is everyone’s duty.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and cares about evidence-based policy, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart design and behavioral nudges rather than just harsher punishment. We should make disposal incredibly convenient (well-placed bins, clear signage, and recycling options), pair that with small but consistently enforced fines, and run public campaigns that frame not littering as a social norm and civic responsibility. Data from environmental psychology and public health suggests that when people see clean, well-maintained spaces and clear expectations, they’re far less likely to treat those spaces like a dumping ground. In other words, if we engineer the environment thoughtfully and back it with science-driven policy, we can dramatically cut litter without relying solely on punitive measures.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks, streets, and venues performing, I see litter as a sign that we’ve stopped feeling connected to the spaces we share. The most effective policies, in my view, combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical tools—plenty of visible bins, bottle-deposit systems, and clear signage—plus arts-driven public campaigns that make caring for our environment feel like a shared, creative responsibility. I’d also support requiring event organizers and businesses to have litter plans and clean-up accountability, so the burden doesn’t just fall on underfunded city crews. When people see that public spaces are treated with respect and beauty, they’re far less likely to trash them.

As someone who cares about my community and the environment, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and real education, especially in schools. Cities should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced, but they should also invest in youth programs and community clean‑ups so people feel responsible for the spaces we all share. When we treat our neighborhoods with respect, especially in places where kids and families spend time, it sends the message that everyone—no matter their background—deserves clean, safe public spaces.

After spending my career as a park ranger, I’ve seen firsthand that strong anti-littering policies only work when they’re backed by both education and enforcement. We need clear signs, plentiful trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders, but we also need to teach kids and adults alike that caring for the land is a shared responsibility. I’d like to see more community clean‑up days, school programs, and public campaigns funded at the local and federal level, so people feel connected to the places they use rather than treating them like dumping grounds. Protecting public spaces from litter isn’t just about cleanliness—it’s about respecting the ecosystems and wildlife that depend on them.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and some firm but fair rules. Folks should be taught from a young age to take pride in their towns and pick up after themselves, and communities can back that up with plenty of trash cans, recycling bins, and clear signage. On top of that, I don’t see a problem with ticketing people who litter—if you mess up the place we all share, there ought to be consequences.

As a preschool teacher and a mom, I see every day how much kids learn from what we model, so strong anti-littering policies should start with education and visible community standards—like plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and school-based programs that make caring for our environment feel normal and proud. I also support reasonable fines and required community clean‑up for repeat offenders, because public spaces belong to all of us, and people should be held accountable when they treat our parks, sidewalks, and playgrounds like a trash can.

As someone who cares about my community and spends a lot of time outside and around people, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and positive community culture. Cities should put out more trash and recycling bins, issue real fines for littering, and invest in public education campaigns—especially in schools and on social media—that frame clean streets as a shared responsibility. I’d also support volunteer clean‑up days organized through churches and local groups, because when people actually help clean their neighborhood, they’re less likely to trash it again.

As someone who spends a lot of time skating around town and hanging out in parks, I see how trash piles up and makes public spaces feel uncared for, especially in neighborhoods like mine. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of real consequences (like fines and community service) and better access to trash and recycling bins, plus school and community programs that teach respect for our environment and each other. If people helped clean up their own blocks together, it would build pride and make folks less likely to just toss stuff on the ground.

Working as an investigator, I’m constantly in public spaces, and it’s striking how much you can learn about a place—and how much respect people have for it—just by looking at the ground. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear, consistently enforced fines and practical supports: enough trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup, and public education that starts in schools. I’d also like to see businesses held responsible for the waste their products generate in public spaces, because individuals shouldn’t shoulder all the blame for a problem driven partly by disposable packaging. When people feel their city is taken care of and that everyone, including corporations, is accountable, they’re far less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about health, both physical and communal, I see littering as a social justice issue: trash doesn’t just make neighborhoods ugly, it disproportionately harms poorer and marginalized communities. The best policies combine strong public investment in frequent trash and recycling pickup, plenty of clearly marked bins, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders, alongside community education that frames clean public spaces as a shared responsibility. I’d also support programs that pay or incentivize local residents—especially those struggling with employment—to help with cleanup and environmental stewardship, so the benefits and the work are distributed more fairly.

As someone who values personal responsibility and enjoys spending time outdoors bird watching and gardening, I believe the best way to prevent littering is strong enforcement of existing laws combined with meaningful fines that actually deter bad behavior. Local governments should keep public spaces well-maintained and provide enough trash and recycling bins, but people need to be held accountable when they disrespect shared spaces. Public campaigns led by community groups and churches, not just bureaucrats, can also help reinforce a culture where littering is seen as shameful and unacceptable.

I was raised to believe you clean up after yourself and respect the land God gave us, and I still feel that way when I’m out in the park or tending my little garden. I think we need stricter enforcement of existing anti-littering laws with meaningful fines and community service, along with more visible trash and recycling bins so there’s no excuse. Schools and churches should also teach personal responsibility and stewardship of the environment from a young age, so people see not littering as a matter of basic manners and morality, not just a rule.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside and on the road delivering food, it honestly ticks me off how much trash people just toss wherever—it makes our towns look terrible and it’s not that hard to use a trash can. I think there should be more trash and recycling bins in busy areas, clear signs, and real fines that actually get enforced when people litter. Schools and churches could also do a better job teaching respect for our communities and God’s creation, so people feel a personal responsibility not to trash the place. In the end, it should be a mix of common-sense rules, enforcement, and personal responsibility, not just one or the other.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks so people don’t have an excuse to drop things on the ground. Grown-ups should put up signs and teach kids at school why litter hurts bugs, animals, and our planet, and maybe give little rewards or stickers when people help clean up.

Where I’m from, folks say “you don’t trash what you love,” and I think that ought to guide our litter policies. The best approach is a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines for littering, plenty of well-placed recycling and trash bins, and bottle-deposit or “pay-as-you-throw” systems that make waste reduction the easy, obvious choice. I’d also love to see cities partner with local businesses and schools on environmental education and neighborhood cleanups, so people feel real pride and ownership over their public spaces.

As someone who cares deeply about the environment and tries to live simply and sustainably, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, convenient trash and recycling bins, and clear, consistently enforced fines. Cities should run ongoing campaigns, especially in schools and churches, to teach that caring for creation is a moral responsibility, not just a legal one. I also think corporations should be held accountable for excess packaging and waste, so the burden isn’t only on individuals doing the right thing.

As someone who’s spent a career in environmental science and still walks our parks and trails with binoculars around my neck, I’ve seen firsthand how litter harms wildlife and degrades the places that keep us healthy and grounded. The most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of strong policy and thoughtful design: clear bans and meaningful fines, abundant and well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and bottle-deposit or extended producer-responsibility laws that make companies share the burden of waste. Equally important are public education campaigns in schools and communities that frame not littering as a shared responsibility to protect our health, our water, and the birds and other creatures we share these spaces with.

As someone who cares about both community spaces and the environment—and works in a data-driven tech field—I think the best anti-litter policies combine smart design, clear accountability, and accessible infrastructure. We should invest in well-placed, clearly labeled trash and recycling bins, pair that with meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and use tech (like sensor-based bins or apps) to optimize maintenance and reporting. Public education campaigns, especially in schools and community centers, are crucial so people see keeping our streets and parks clean as a shared civic responsibility, not just a rule to avoid breaking.

At my age, having watched this country change over many decades, I’m convinced the best way to prevent littering is to reinforce personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces, not just pass new regulations. Clear, consistently enforced fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and community service requirements for offenders would help, but we also need schools, churches, and local civic groups to teach younger generations that caring for our streets and parks is simply part of good citizenship and moral duty.

I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of strict enforcement and personal responsibility. Clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for violators send the message that public spaces are shared assets we all must care for. At the same time, we should invest in straightforward public education campaigns that appeal to people’s pride in their community rather than relying on feel-good slogans.

As someone who takes pride in keeping things neat, both at work cleaning hotel rooms and at home in my garden, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and practical measures. We should have more clearly marked trash and recycling cans, reasonable fines for people who litter, and community clean‑up days that get neighbors involved and teach respect for our shared spaces. I don’t think we need a lot of new big-government programs—just common-sense rules that are enforced, and families and churches setting a good example for the younger generation.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins everywhere, and they should have fun superhero pictures on them so kids want to use them. Schools and communities could do “cleanup days” where families and friends work together to pick up litter, and you get a sticker or small prize for helping. If we learn from a young age not to litter, and see our heroes and parents doing the right thing, people will be more careful about keeping our parks and sidewalks clean.

As someone who runs a hardware store and spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and watching birds, I think preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and enforcing the laws we already have. Cities and towns should impose real fines for littering and actually follow through, but also make it easy to do the right thing by keeping plenty of trash and recycling bins in parks, parking lots, and along busy streets. I’d rather see local communities and businesses work together on cleanup days and education than rely on big new government programs.

As someone who cares about keeping my neighborhood clean and volunteers at my church, I think we need both personal responsibility and firm consequences to cut down on littering. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins in busy areas and keep them emptied regularly, but they should also enforce fines and community service for folks who keep trashing our streets. Teaching kids in schools and through church and community programs to respect God’s creation and take pride in their town would go a long way, too.

As someone who values both personal freedom and personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to make individuals directly accountable for their own mess—through strict, consistently enforced fines and clear rules, not bloated new programs. I’d pair that with plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, plus community-driven clean‑up efforts run by volunteers and local groups rather than top‑down mandates. When people see their neighbors taking pride in shared spaces, they’re more likely to respect them.

Working in a nursing facility, I see every day how a clean environment affects people’s health and dignity, so I think our public spaces deserve that same respect. I support a mix of strict enforcement with real fines for littering, more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, and clear public education starting in schools so kids learn early. I don’t want cameras or invasive surveillance just to catch litterers, but I do think community service cleaning public areas is a fair consequence that teaches responsibility. Ultimately, keeping our neighborhoods clean should be a shared responsibility, not something we leave to underpaid workers to deal with.

As someone who cares about keeping our community clean and safe for families, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, clear rules, and consistent enforcement. We should have visible trash and recycling bins, firm fines for those who litter, and community or church-led clean-up days that remind people to take pride in the places we share.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors, I’d like to see stronger, common-sense policies to keep our public spaces clean—things like clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup programs, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders. But we also need education, especially in schools and community groups, that teaches people to take pride in shared spaces and respect the work it takes to maintain them. Public campaigns and volunteer cleanup days can build that sense of responsibility, so it’s not just about punishment but about community stewardship.
